awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Exploration of marine biology on the Oregon coast
awd_abstract_narration:
A new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Oregon Eugene's Oregon Institute of Marine Biology (OIMB) located in Charleston, OR will be developed with this award. The program will support a total of ten students each summer for a nine-week research program. The project model includes offering research opportunities to students from 2-year colleges using a tiered learning model with pairs of students working with mentors to conduct research. Funding supports student stipends, housing and student travel expenses from their home to the site.  A total of thirty students will gain experience in scientific research and participate in a variety of professional development workshops during the three years of the grant.

Students will have the opportunity to conduct research in a wide range of biological sciences, including research on the ecology of invertebrate embryos, larvae, and juveniles; trophic interactions in food webs; biology and systematics of the ribbon worms; ecological interactions of organisms with coastal physical oceanographic and environmental processes; the ecology and hydromechanical function in gelatinous zooplankton; cell biology; estuarine fish and invertebrate ecology, and the ecology of deep-sea and subtidal invertebrates.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Oregon Institute of Marine Biology/Univ Oregon

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The Oregon Institute of Marine Biology (OIMB) ran an REU-site program, Exploration of Marine Biology on the Oregon Coast (EMBOC) for 3 summers (2017-2019).  Each summer we engaged 11 interns (33 total) in nine weeks of mentored research.  Fifteen interns from 4yr colleges were paired with 18 interns from 2yr colleges in a tiered learning model in research labs at OIMB and the South Slough National Estuarine Research Reserve and worked full-time on research projects with one of 10 mentors. Our program worked toward our and NSF?s shared goal of increasing mentored research opportunities for groups underrepresented in STEM, by recruiting diverse cohorts of interns. 18 of 33 EMBOC interns identified with groups underrepresented in STEM (e.g. Hispanic, African American, Native American, Asian American, Pacific Islander, multiracial and 1st generation).  Three additional interns from 4yr colleges were supported by this grant in subsequent years as the program continued under a new REU-site grant (OCE-1950520).  

In addition to research, cohorts of interns also participated in weekly professional develop workshops covering topics on using library resources, reading scientific literature, ethics in research, diversity and inclusivity in science, preparing CV?s, finding jobs and applying to graduate school, and science communication (e.g. creating and presenting scientific talks posters, conveying science to a broader public audience).   They also presented their research to a public audience in 3-hour sessions at the Charleston Marine Life Center associated with OIMB. Last, interns wrote a weekly blog post describing their research challenges and triumphs, experience in professional development and social excursions on the Oregon Coast, see https://uoregonoimb-reu.weebly.com/.

Each intern produced and presented a scientific poster on their research project at the end of each summer to an audience including OIMB faculty, students, interested members of the SW Oregon scientific community, and the public.  Twenty-one (including 8 from 2yr colleges) of these 36 interns also attended and presented their research at regional or national scientific meetings.  Three scientific papers were published, with interns as co-authors.  

Comparative surveys of interns conducted at the beginning and end of each summer showed that almost all interns gained significant understanding of how science is done: gains in their perceived research skills and confidence in ability to conduct meaningful research. Interns also reported change in educational and career goals toward pursuing graduate degrees and careers in STEM fields and were very pleased to have been part of this learning and research experience.

At the time of this report (March 2023), 17 of 18 interns from 2YR colleges transferred to 4YR colleges and 2 are still in college.  27 interns of 33 in the first 3 cohorts continued with some research, 13 went on to graduate school, 17 had STEM related jobs and four others had non-STEM jobs after our program.


Last Modified: 03/04/2023
Modified by: Richard B Emlet
